thread.title: Ohio wins $71 million charter school expansion grant, drawing pride and distrust
thread.title_full: Ohio wins $71 million charter school expansion grant, drawing pride and distrust | cleveland.com

author: Patrick O'Donnell, The Plain Dealer
title: Ohio wins $71 million charter school expansion grant, drawing pride and distrust
text:
COLUMBUS, Ohio -- The Ohio Department of Education is offering few clues about how it will hand out $71 million in charter school expansion money that the U.S. Department of Education awarded the state this week.
Though the grant is designed to expand high quality charter schools across the state over the next five years, critics are howling that the department will be allowed to choose who receives the money when it couldn't follow the law in charter school oversight evaluations.
"It's very hard to have confidence in ODE's ability to serve as a fair and impartial evaluator of charter school operations in light of what happened in the effort to mask the poor performance of online schools," said Becky Higgins, president of the Ohio Education Association .
National publications, including the Washington Post, were also quick to point out several Ohio charter school controversies in reporting on the grant awards.
Federal officials said today that Ohio's grant comes with "special conditions."
"Those conditions include requiring the state to submit quarterly reports on its grant activities and budget," said U.S. Department of Education Press Secretary Dorie Nolt. "We will continue to monitor Ohio – and all grantees – to ensure they are serving children well."
The ODE's rating of the academic performance of charters came into question earlier this year, following a June Plain Dealer report that it deliberately left out the F grades of online schools -- some of which were created by large Republican donors -- from those evaluations.
The department's former school choice chief David Hansen, husband of Gov. John Kasich's presidential campaign manager Beth Hansen, resigned in July over that decision, even as the U.S. Department of Education was reviewing the grant applications.
Federal evaluators found shortcomings in Ohio's application, but they had mostly glowing reports of Ohio's evaluation process for oversight agencies and still awarded Ohio the $71 million - the most money out of the seven states and the District of Columbia that are sharing a total of $249 million.
Each of the other states -- Arizona, Colorado, Illinois, Oregon, Nevada, South Carolina -- also will pass out the money themselves, under criteria set in each state.
ODE spokesperson Kim Norris said the department is "proud" to win the grant and the money will help to expand strong charter schools in the state.
She said the state informed the federal department about the issues with the oversight evaluations weeks ago. Ohio will keep working with the DOE about what criteria to use in selecting schools to receive grants.
"The actual specifics of that will be determined," Norris said.
Norris said Ohio's grant lets the state "expand high quality community (charter) schools by providing financial assistance for the planning, program design and implementation of community schools; evaluating the schools' effect on students and student achievement, staff and parents; and disseminating information about successful practices."
Secretary of Education Arne Duncan said the Charter School Program grants allow high-performing charter school models to replicate in high-need communities, serving kids in need of strong educational choices.
Ohio previously received a similar grant, then was not renewed a few years ago, before winning it again.
Lyman Millard, spokesman for the Breakthrough charter school network here in Cleveland, said Breakthrough schools received money from these grants to start some of its schools several years ago.
It later won a grant of nearly $3.5 million directly from the federal government, in the gap when ODE was not a recipient, to help start some of its existing schools.
Starting a new charter school, he said, costs a lot of money -- beyond the daily cost of operating. Federal grants, he said, were key to having Breakthrough expand a network that many consider the strongest in the state.
"It will make it easier for the high quality schools to have the startup funds they need to open more schools," he said.
And, Millard said adding strong charter schools helps weed out weaker ones.
"This just allows the state to crowd out the market a little bit with high-performing schools and puts a little pressure on low performing schools -- economic pressure, enrollment pressure," he said.
He said the state had a rigorous application process for the grants in previous years.
State Sen. Peggy Lehner , chair of the Senate Education Committee, said there are strong charter school operators in other states who don't come to Ohio, supposedly because of a lack of support with startup costs, among other reasons.
Lehner said she hoped these grants might draw some to start schools in Ohio.
Higgins renewed calls for an outside investigation into ODE's handling of the evaluations of charter oversight agencies, known as "sponsors" or "authorizers." She said an investigation, also sought by some state school board members and the Ohio Democratic Party, "would help restore the public's faith that ODE is capable of acting in the best interest of Ohio's students."
State Superintendent Richard Ross doesn't want an investigation , other than by the state auditor or inspector general -- both Republicans. The state school board agreed with him earlier this month, tabling a move to hire an outsider .
Whether ODE employees involved in those sponsor evaluations will have any say in how this new federal money is awarded is unclear.
While Ross has said that Hansen acted alone in his decision, several other ODE employees were involved in researching it and discussing the evaluations . Ross later revised his comments to say no one other than people working under Hansen knew of the omission.
And though Hansen is gone, many of those employees, including ODE's charter school director Joni Hoffman, are still with the department. She's not talking about her involvement.
